model_answer: The answer is A/B/C. In event 6, Kumar explained that CASHAA is a utility token with many users and that a large share of funds came in dollars, highlighting a need to serve mainstream buyers beyond typical crypto exchange users. This implies that there was a demand for a simple purchasing experience for those who were not familiar with cryptocurrency exchanges. In event 7, Kumar stated that many buyers were not ready to purchase on any exchange, often buying with USD due to money transfer or banking problems, which shows exchange readiness barriers in the user base. This also implies a need for a simpler purchasing experience. In event 8, despite listings on top exchanges, people kept emailing to buy directly from the company for legitimacy and trust, indicating demand for a company-operated, simplified purchase path.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on business ethics for help. Kumar rejects around $14.7 million during the token sale because of regulatory issues related to AML (anti-money laundering) and KYC (Know Your Customer) policies.

Therefore, the answer is (A).
